chapter.title: The Action menu
chapter.para: From the Actions menu, the user can access the Preferences and configure the Maestro/Nodes settings. If the user's enthusiasm for GêBR has lead to read the whole manual, then the user has probably used almost all available features found in these options. But just in case, the user will find the documentation for these options below.

section.title: Preferences
section.para: The details the user provides in the Preferences dialog box will be adopted as the default by GêBR. Specifically:

listitem.para: User name: will be used as the default for Author, when the user creates projects, lines and flows.
Email: will be used as the default for Email, when the user creates projects, lines and flows.
User's menus directory: will be the default directory where GêBR's Menus are maintained (mnu files).

mediaobject.caption: Preferences menu opens a dialog box where the user edits the user's name, e-mail, menu's directory and the HTML editor.

section.title: Connection assistant
section.para: This option helps the user to configure all the necessary connections to work properly GêBR.
The connection assistant explains the user to connect to a maestro, its servers and enable remote browsing (for more information, see and ).

section.title: Maestro/Nodes configuration
section.para: The Maestro/Nodes InterfaceMaestroNode has three parts:

listitem.para: Nodes: choose the nodes associated to the current maestro.
GroupsNode group of: configure the groups of nodes on the current maestro.

mediaobject.caption: The Maestro/Nodes configuration interface is divided in three parts: maestro, list of nodes and groups of nodes.

section.title: Maestro
section.para: In the upper part of the Maestro/Nodes Interface (see ), there is an entry in which the user can put the desired machine to use as maestro. A requirement is that the maestro must be installed on that machine. The state of the connection between GêBR and the maestro is shown by the right-side icon:

section.title: Nodes
section.para: Once the maestro has been selected and the connection has been successfully established, the user can associate nodes Node to that maestro.
Each line of the nodes window represents each machine associated to the maestro. The lines have some columns:

listitem.para: AC: checkbox to activate or not the auto-connection to that node.
MPI: depicts whether the machine has support to MPIMPI.
Address: hostname or IP address of the node.
CPU Clock: CPU clock of the node.
Memory: total memory of the machine.

section.para: The user can add a new machine by clicking over New and entering the hostname or IP address of the machine.

section.title: Groups
section.para: It's possible to employ a subset of the machines associated to the maestroProcessing nodesgroup of. This can be done through the creation of groups of machines.
The administration of the groups is in the bottom part of the Maestro/Nodes interface (see ).

To create a group, click over a node in the list and drag it to the
icon. A text box will be prompted for the name of the group. Groups with same names are not allowed.

example.para:
Using groups is very useful when it's necessary to run a flow in a subset of machines different from the default (For more information, see
). That's useful, Because sometimes it's desired save resources from some processing nodes to not overload all of them.

For example:
Choose a subset of processing nodes Create a group with them. Give a name for the group.
Create a parallelizable flow (see
).
Open the Execution settings window on Flows tab (see
).
Set the maximum number of cores (nominal capacity) to execute the flow.
Set the group node desired. Press run.
Go to Jobs tab.
Click on Details.
See the nodes group in which the flow was executed (see
).
It's easy to see that the execution was distributed in the nodes of subset (group) chosen by the user and not in all the processing nodes.
